thread.title: Raptors need Terrence Ross to adapt to new role quickly
thread.title_full: Raptors need Terrence Ross to adapt to new role quickly | Toronto Star

author: Doug Smith
title: Raptors need Terrence Ross to adapt to new role quickly
text:
MONTREAL—There is a quietness to Terrence Ross, the Raptors guard is not truly shy but he is reserved and never seems to be in too much of a hurry.
That passivity can lead to moments of infuriating frustration for his teammates and coaches who know that under that laissez-faire demeanour lives a gifted athlete and a potentially excellent basketball player.
They know what he can do, but get perturbed by his long stretches of inconsistency and know if the team is to realize many of its goals this season, Ross has to basically change who he is.
Moved to a role coming off the bench and charged with immediately infusing a game with energy and scoring, teammates privately wonder if he can do it while coaches publicly assert that he must.
“He’s going to have to get used to coming in and being productive quickly,” Raptors coach Dwane Casey said of the 24-year-old Ross, who is entering his fourth NBA season. “You don’t have time to get loose and get a feel for the game. You have to come in ready to play defence, ready to shoot that three or a jump shot or whatever you have.
“You have to be almost in a lather when you come off the bench. He’s adjusted to it, he’s had the whole summer knowing . . . so the mindset is there.”
On July 9, the day the Raptors signed free agent DeMarre Carroll was the day Ross became a backup, so the six-foot-seven native of Portland has had time to prepare himself for a new job that includes much more responsibility.
The Raptors’ second unit is not chock full of offensive ability and it will fall on Ross to be the team’s primary scorer off the bench, and he’ll have to do it quickly each night. There will be no chance to ease into a game, to gauge its flow before picking his spots.
“It’s an opportunity to have a big role in the offence and have a big role defensively, doing it all,” Ross said here Friday. “I just get to be more assertive early . . . you have to come out and instead of waiting for someone to get you involved, you have to actually go out there and make something happen yourself.”
Ross was an integral part of what will be Toronto’s primary regular season rotation here Friday night.
Coming off the bench about seven minutes in the first quarter of a 92-82 win over the Washington Wizards at the Bell Centre, he had an innocuous three points in 23 minutes as the pre-season wrapped up.
Doing what he said he would, Casey stretched out his regulars to much closer to regular season minutes, using nine players into the fourth quarter before turning to Anthony Bennett and Delon Wright.
The most telling decision was starting Luis Scola over Patrick Patterson , but the nine who are expected to log the bulk of the minutes did.
Carroll had 16 points, Kyle Lowry 13, DeMar DeRozan and Jonas Valanciunas had 12 apiece for the Raptors.
Ross’s reasons for needing a big season go beyond just helping the Raptors have an excellent season — there’s money at stake.
He will become a restricted free agent in July if he and the Raptors don’t agree on a contract extension by Nov. 1, and a good seson could put him in line for a substantial raise from his current salary of about $3.5 million (U.S.).
His agent and the Raptors have had some minor talks about a new deal but the franchise is not about to overpay in money or years for a young player who has yet to put together a good full season. They would do a deal in a minute strictly on their terms, but Ross and his representatives know it could be more lucrative to hold off if he’s sure he’ll have a breakout season in his new role.
“It’d be an honour to get it but if it doesn’t happen, it doesn’t happen,” Ross said.
